title: Cats. 108–110 Three Mold-Blown Vessels
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Bottle  
1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mold-blown; 6.8 × 4.5 × 2.5 cm (2 5/8 × 1 3/4 × 1 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1943.1181

Jug  
First half of the 1st century A.D.  
Roman, coast of Syria or Palestine  
Glass, mold-blown; 9.7 × 5.4 × 5.1 cm (3 7/8 × 2 1/8 × 2 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1943.1171

Bottle in the Shape of a Date  
1st/mid-2nd century A.D.  
Roman, coast of Syria or Palestine  
Glass, mold-blown; 6.2 × 2.6 × 2.9 cm (2 7/16 × 1 × 1 1/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.435

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">These three vessels offer a glimpse of the diversity of form and the ingenuity of glassblowers in the eastern Roman Empire in the first century A.D. While the group of three hexagonal mold-blown bottles (cats. 105–107) illustrates the variation of color and design within a single form, these contemporary vessels show how the glassmakers employed delicate and precise decorative elements to create a wide variety of design on numerous inventive forms. The bottle with heads (cat. 108) appears to be a unique example of this type of decoration, while the small jug (cat. 109) is defined by a register with delicate tendrils and elegant form that may suggest that it was produced at one of the major glass factories in Sidon. The bottle in the shape of a date (cat. 110) is far more popular and is commonly preserved in the yellow-brown color of the fruit it represents. There are a few examples of this form blown in green or deep-blue glass. All of these small vessels were containers for precious liquids, probably scented oils that were shipped throughout the empire.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Three mold-blown vessels, from left: Bottle, 1st century A.D. (cat. 108); Jug, 1st half of the 1st century A.D. (cat. 109); Bottle in the Shape of a Date, 1st/mid-2nd century A.D. (cat. 110).

</section>
